questions.question: What are the assessment components and their weightings for COMP3331/9331?
What are the prerequisites and assumed knowledge for COMP3331/9331?
What is the required textbook for the Computer Networks course?
answer: Computer Networking: A Top Down Approach

questions.question: What are the main course aims for COMP3331/9331?
answer: overview of core topics in computer networks

questions.question: How are labs structured in the Computer Networks course?
What is VLAB and how is it used in the course?
What are the main learning objectives about the Internet in this course?
What follow-on courses are available after completing COMP3331/9331?

COMP6733: Internet of Things Design Studio

questions.question: What are the five layers of the Internet protocol stack and their main functions?
How much network capacity is required for circuit switching with 100 users each sending 1 Mbps when active?
What is the expected aggregate traffic in a packet-switched network with 100 users, each active with probability 0.2 and sending 1 Mbps when active?
What are the three main networking design steps?
answer: Break down the problem into tasks

questions.question: What are the main tasks involved in networking to send packets across networks?
answer: Ensure packets get to destination process
Deliver packets within local network to next hop

questions.question: What are two main benefits of using a layered network model?
answer: makes it easy to introduce new protocols
prevents technology in one layer from affecting other layers

questions.question: What are the potential harmful effects of layering in networks?
answer: TCP + IP + Ethernet headers add up to 54 bytes

questions.question: Which protocol layers are implemented on routers versus hosts?
answer: routers implement physical, datalink, network layers

questions.question: What is encapsulation in the context of network protocol layers?
Does queuing delay at a router depend on the length of the outgoing link?
answer: queuing happens because transmission rate is insufficient
length of link does not typically impact queuing
transmission rate more important than link length

questions.question: What support resources are available for students in this course?
What are the consequences of plagiarism in this course?
answer: publicly accessible code repositories assumed to be plagiarism

questions.question: What are the main differences between packet switching and circuit switching?
answer: packet switching can have congestion and delays

questions.question: What are the four sources of packet delay in networks?
What are the main types of access network technologies for connecting homes to the Internet?
What are the key components that make up the Internet infrastructure?
What determines the throughput in a network connection?
What are the main types of physical media used in computer networks?

What is statistical multiplexing and why is it used in packet switching?
answer: assumption that not all flows burst simultaneously

questions.question: What are the different tiers in the Internet's hierarchical structure?
What causes packet loss in networks?
answer: arrival rate exceeds output link capacity

questions.question: What are the key differences between client-server and peer-to-peer network architectures?
answer: Client-server: always-on server, permanent IP address, clients contact server, clients may be intermittently connected
Peer-to-peer: no always-on server, arbitrary end systems communicate directly, self scalability, peers intermittently connected

questions.question: What are the main HTTP request methods and their purposes?
answer: POST: sends user input to server in entity body

questions.question: What services does TCP provide compared to UDP for network applications?
answer: TCP: reliable transport, flow control, congestion control, connection-oriented
UDP: unreliable data transfer, no flow control, no congestion control, no connection setup

questions.question: How does persistent HTTP improve performance compared to non-persistent HTTP?
answer: Persistent HTTP: server leaves TCP connection open, multiple objects sent over same connection, allows TCP to learn accurate RTT estimate
Non-persistent HTTP: at most one object per TCP connection, requires multiple connections

questions.question: What are HTTP cookies and what are their main components?
answer: Cookie header line in HTTP response message
Cookie header line in HTTP request message
Cookie file kept on user's host

questions.question: How do web caches and proxy servers improve HTTP performance?
answer: Satisfy client requests without involving origin server
Reduce response time for client requests
Reduce traffic on institution's access link
Cache acts as both client and server

questions.question: What are the main components of the email system architecture?
What do common HTTP response status codes indicate?
answer: 301 Moved Permanently: object moved to new location

questions.question: What transport service requirements do different network applications have?
answer: Data integrity: some apps require 100% reliable transfer, others tolerate loss
Timing: some apps require low delay
Throughput: some require minimum throughput, others are elastic

questions.question: How does SMTP protocol work for email message transfer?
answer: Three phases: handshaking, message transfer, closure
Command/response interaction with ASCII text commands
Direct transfer from sending server to receiving server

Why is rdt3.0 needed instead of rdt2.2?
What is the main difference between Go-Back-N and Selective Repeat protocols?

What is TCP flow control and how is it implemented?

questions.question: What field in the IP header identifies the higher-level protocol?
What are the two main approaches to structuring network control plane in routing?
What are the main characteristics of Link State routing algorithms?
answer: each node maintains its local link state
each node floods its local link state to all nodes
eventually each node learns the entire network topology
uses Dijkstra's algorithm to compute shortest paths

questions.question: What is the Bellman-Ford equation used in Distance Vector routing?
answer: cost of least-cost path from x to y
minimum taken over all neighbors v of x

questions.question: What is the count-to-infinity problem in Distance Vector routing?
answer: slow convergence when link costs increase
routers may count up to large numbers before converging

questions.question: What is the poisoned reverse technique in Distance Vector routing?
answer: if B routes via C to get to A
B tells C its distance to A is infinite
prevents C from routing to A via B

questions.question: How do Link State and Distance Vector algorithms compare in terms of message complexity?
answer: LS: n routers, O(n2) messages sent

questions.question: What are some real protocols that implement Link State and Distance Vector algorithms?
answer: Link State: Open Shortest Path First (OSPF)
Link State: Intermediate system to intermediate system (IS-IS)
Distance Vector: Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (IGRP-Cisco)
Distance Vector: Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) - variant

questions.question: What is ICMP and what is it used for?
answer: used by hosts and routers to communicate network level information
error reporting: unreachable host, network, port

questions.question: How does Dijkstra's algorithm work in link-state routing?
answer: centralized: network topology and link costs known to all nodes
computes least cost paths from one node to all other nodes
iterative: after k iterations, know least cost path to k destinations
gives forwarding table for that node

questions.question: What are the key differences between data plane and control plane in network layer?
answer: forwarding: move packets from router input to appropriate router output
routing: determine route taken by packets from source to destination

questions.question: What are the three private IP address ranges defined in RFC 1918?
What are the main advantages of using Network Address Translation (NAT)?
answer: just one IP address needed from provider ISP for all devices
can change addresses of host in local network without notifying outside world
can change ISP without changing addresses of devices in local network
security: devices inside local net not directly addressable, visible by outside world

questions.question: What are the three solutions mentioned for NAT traversal problems?
answer: Inbound-NAT Statically configure NAT to forward incoming connection requests
Universal Plug and Play (UPnP) Internet Gateway Device (IGD) Protocol

questions.question: What are the main motivations for developing IPv6?
answer: 32-bit IPv4 address space would be completely allocated
enable different network-layer treatment of flows

questions.question: What features are missing in IPv6 compared to IPv4?
What is tunneling in the context of IPv4 to IPv6 transition?
answer: IPv6 datagram carried as payload in IPv4 datagram among IPv4 routers

questions.question: What practical issues does NAT face when modifying packets?
answer: requires recalculation of TCP and IP checksum
some applications embed IP address or port numbers in their message payloads

questions.question: According to Google statistics, what percentage of clients access services via IPv6?
How does NAT implement address translation for outgoing datagrams?
answer: replace source IP address, port # of every outgoing datagram to NAT IP address, new port #
remember every translation pair in NAT translation table
remote clients/servers will respond using NAT IP address, new port # as destination address

questions.question: What are the controversial aspects of NAT mentioned in the document?
answer: routers should only process up to layer 3
address shortage should be solved by IPv6
NAT traversal: what if client wants to connect to server behind NAT

questions.question: What are the main error detection and correction methods used in data link layer protocols?
What are the three broad categories of MAC protocols for multiple access control?
What are the key services provided by the data link layer?
How does CSMA/CD handle collisions in Ethernet networks?
What are the advantages and disadvantages of slotted ALOHA protocol?
answer: single active node transmits at full rate

questions.question: What are the key differences between MAC addresses and IP addresses in terms of structure and portability?
answer: MAC addresses are 48-bit flat addresses that are hard-coded and portable
IP addresses are 32-bit hierarchical addresses that are learned dynamically and not portable
MAC addresses stay the same as host moves
IP addresses depend on where the host is attached

questions.question: How does the ARP protocol work to resolve IP addresses to MAC addresses?
answer: Host broadcasts ARP query containing target IP address
All nodes on LAN receive ARP query
Target host replies with ARP response containing its MAC address
Requesting host adds entry to local ARP table
ARP table entries have TTL typically 20 minutes

questions.question: What are the main characteristics and advantages of Ethernet switches compared to hubs?
answer: Switches are link-layer devices that store and forward frames
Each link is its own collision domain with no collisions

answer: DES uses 56-bit key and 64-bit plaintext input
AES replaced DES with 128, 192, or 256 bit keys
AES processes data in 128 bit blocks
